results.content: The subject matter is exactly what I need so spot on there. I like the pace at which the presenter is going at, nice and slow. However, at this point some of the diagrams are not really helping that much in visualising the abstract concept of async. Perhaps, break down the arrangement of an async function and show us in pieces how that relates to the operation of the hardware and event loop. At this stage, the code, and the diagrams do not seem connected in my head. Hoping that as the course progresses, these points will be addressed

results.content:
The course has been well planned and executed, thus far, only I have noticed code that could have been more efficiently written and easily readable.

It is my opinion that just because we CAN inline certain statements or blocks of code in es6, it doesn't mean we should inline everything. And removing curly braces just because we can, makes code unreadable to the masses. But, this is code style - I digress.

response.content: Thanks for the feedback Jonathan! I agree with you 100% - normally lean more towards being verbose for clarity esp. when teaching, less inlining of statements etc... not sure when I did the opposite in this course, feel free to comment on the relevant lectures and I'll take a look :)

response.content: Hi Avraham, thanks for your feedback. The subtitles are automatically generated by Udemy - I have forwarded your concerns to them. Regarding the lecture on how to install NodeJS, if you are comfortable with that then feel free to skip! :) I need to make sure the course caters for people of all skill levels which is why I explain everything from the basics, but if you are comfortable with setup then feel free to skip. Please don't skip the lectures themselves though, even if you think it's easy and you already know it, future lectures depend on earlier lectures and if you skip then future lectures might not make sense.
response.content_html: Hi Avraham, thanks for your feedback. The subtitles are automatically generated by Udemy - I have forwarded your concerns to them. Regarding the lecture on how to install NodeJS, if you are comfortable with that then feel free to skip! :) I need to make sure the course caters for people of all skill levels which is why I explain everything from the basics, but if you are comfortable with setup then feel free to skip. Please don't skip the lectures themselves though, even if you think it's easy and you already know it, future lectures depend on earlier lectures and if you skip then future lectures might not make sense.

results.content: The information for the course was very good, but some of the presentation could be refactored for clarity. For instance, the callback section is a complete mess, unclear, confusing and not well delivered. I don't think the "Quiz" method of educating is appropriate here. Another sticking point was the Event Loop section. It is little more than an incomplete overview of Event Loops, and although the examples dig deeper, the section could be fleshed out better. I do enjoy Asim's presentations.

results.content: Clear and professional presentation.  The instructor assumes that the student is comfortable with Javascript.  If you are new to Javascript you will get lost quickly.  But I took the course as a relative newbie and got a lot out of it.  The strength of the course is the fact that Asim uses the same file processing task over and over and challenges the user to re-code the task with his latest instruction.  So the user must re-think the same task, allowing us to focus on javascript and not different problems.
results.content_html: Clear and professional presentation. The instructor assumes that the student is comfortable with Javascript. If you are new to Javascript you will get lost quickly. But I took the course as a relative newbie and got a lot out of it. The strength of the course is the fact that Asim uses the same file processing task over and over and challenges the user to re-code the task with his latest instruction. So the user must re-think the same task, allowing us to focus on javascript and not different problems.

results.content: Great course that covers Async JavaScript. Really cleared a few areas up that I was confused about. The instructor may like to use trick questions on the quizzes, but some of them are really useful in driving home concepts. Overall I am glad I took this course!

results.content: Excellent Course on Async Javascript - clear, detailed and precise descriptions, slides and useful node code examples and quizzes. Particularly valued the Event Loop explanations on Node which shed light on the nitty-gritty phase processing, useful to understand why the Node API calls behave the way they do ! Improvement point would be to provide more details on why the newer Async Generator custom iterators are the best approach w examples - Many Thanks Asim !
results.content_html: Excellent Course on Async Javascript - clear, detailed and precise descriptions, slides and useful node code examples and quizzes. Particularly valued the Event Loop explanations on Node which shed light on the nitty-gritty phase processing, useful to understand why the Node API calls behave the way they do ! Improvement point would be to provide more details on why the newer Async Generator custom iterators are the best approach w examples - Many Thanks Asim !

results.content:
I'm enjoying the course. Although, I am using google a lot to understand each quiz instead of using what I learned from each lecture. And to be fair, with a language this diverse, Google + MDN tends to be the standard approach to finding ideas. I would appreciate more elaboration on the why the code is behaving asynchronously in combination with using various techniques. Diving into the behind the scenes.

Update: Now that I've finished the course, I did achieve the knowledge I was seeking. And answered the fundamental questions I had on callbacks and asynchronous code usage. The course style is more to learn about what each is, then to try something. But it's not the spoon fed... don't think style. You do have to think about each quiz. I feel, because I worked thoughtfully on each quiz, the information will be better retained.

results.content:
I was skeptical of the "quiz before teaching/knowing" idea at first, but it actually worked really well - I spent a few minutes "trying" to do what was asked, and then realised I couldn't, but the exercise proved useful. Then finding out there were some 'trick' questions and the WHY/WHY-NOT helped make it all make sense. I was really looking for some good grounding on callbacks/Promises/Async-Await and this course had that, so thanks very much. The stuff on Generators, Event Queue, etc. were all helpful and informative, a nice bonus for me.
My only suggestion: instead of having to do console.log("Moo " + err) etc, just have your reject() or whatever return something more unique than "Error", like "An error occurred" - then it's more obvious. Likewise, avoid things like: let promise = new Promise(..) -- the recycling of words introduces unnecessary ambiguity in an instructional course. Better maybe: let myPromise = new Promise(). Unlike  in real-life, in teaching there's a benefit to being wordy and more clear. Also some spell checking of the .MD files would help :)
But overall, the course helped me learn what I was looking for, the quizzes/exercises helped a lot. Thanks.
results.content_html:
I was skeptical of the "quiz before teaching/knowing" idea at first, but it actually worked really well - I spent a few minutes "trying" to do what was asked, and then realised I couldn't, but the exercise proved useful. Then finding out there were some 'trick' questions and the WHY/WHY-NOT helped make it all make sense. I was really looking for some good grounding on callbacks/Promises/Async-Await and this course had that, so thanks very much. The stuff on Generators, Event Queue, etc. were all helpful and informative, a nice bonus for me.
My only suggestion: instead of having to do console.log("Moo " + err) etc, just have your reject() or whatever return something more unique than "Error", like "An error occurred" - then it's more obvious. Likewise, avoid things like: let promise = new Promise(..) -- the recycling of words introduces unnecessary ambiguity in an instructional course. Better maybe: let myPromise = new Promise(). Unlike in real-life, in teaching there's a benefit to being wordy and more clear. Also some spell checking of the .MD files would help :)
But overall, the course helped me learn what I was looking for, the quizzes/exercises helped a lot. Thanks.

results.content: This course is enlightening.  It gets off to a bit of a slow start if you are experienced, but stay with it, and it soon becomes challenging.  The examples are well thought out, and build on each other in a way that shows careful planning by the instructor to move the student along one new concept at a time.  By the end of the course, you are sure to have learned a lot about asynchronous JavaScript, especially as it is appears in Node.js.  Looking forward to more JavaScript and Node.js from Asim in his future course offerings.

response.content: Thanks Jim, glad it helped you :)

The examples are well thought out, and build on each other in a way that shows careful planning by the instructor to move the student along one new concept at a time. By the end of the course, you are sure to have learned a lot about asynchronous JavaScript, especially as it is appears in Node.js. Looking forward to more JavaScript and Node.js from Asim in his future course offerings.

results.content:
This is the first time I had to request a refund for a course on Udemy. How am I supposed to solve quizzes if I don't know the basic theory of the methods I am trying to learn?

Every second quiz is a "trick question". Meanwhile, the instructor always makes sure to let students know to only look at the solution "when I tell you to" and to "try it a few minutes".

I am not a beginner in JS, but I have always avoided the concept of asynchronous JS and thought this course would give me a good understanding. Instead, I have now waisted 2 hours with this course and decided to give up now.

The methodology is flawed. I initially got this course with a coupon - still requesting a refund. If I had paid the full amount, I would have been seriously annoyed.

The speaker is excelent and the course is fantastic. If you develop professionally you'll find yourself using these concepts with ease.

results.content:
An amazing course, I thought I had enough knowledge on asynchronous programming - but I realized it was just enough to read and write code that is more or less understandable in terms of what is happening in the flow. 

Some of the concepts were explained so well that I now have a much clearer image in my head of how it works - in terms of async/await with promises - how and when to use them, their benefits and shortfalls. 

Another thing that I found really, really helpful was the section on event loops. I never knew this was a thing - and understanding how it works, makes reading previous answers on stack overflow (in regards to setTimeout, setInterval, requestAnimationFrame, etc) make so much more sense as you know why it is behaving the way it is. (And why some of these are only available in some containers like node vs browsers)

All an all, great course, the lecturer is easy to understand and speaks clearly. Would recommend to anyone interested in learning/diving deeper into asynchronous programming in JavaScript.

response.content: Wow thanks for the great review Johan!
response.content_html: Wow thanks for the great review Johan!

results.content:
This course is for those who are already familiar with JavaScript in a good way.  They are short modules with intermittent quizzes for you to solve, and I highly suggest as the author does to give a go at them. 

For me it was a good way to really understand how async code works and how to handle them. I've learned a lot how to deal with promises and the good and bad things about async - await

I skipped making your own iterators and also generators, but I understand the concept of generators. This course is for intermediate / advanced javascript developers

results.content:
Good course. The in depth explanations about how computers work (related to the asynchronicity) was fascinating. And the event-loop section was great. However, using the markdown files was annoying (for anyone who isn't using visual studio code, it would have been simpler for us to just install node and run the files from our machine). Also, the quizzes were pretty unclear, and not actually very helpful for understanding the asynchronous functions. Could have used some more real-world examples to get a sense of what the purpose is of all this code. Was difficult to care because I didn't really understand why each of these features (generators, process.nextTick, etc.) would be used.

EDIT -- Quick response from the instructor! Thanks!
results.content_html:
